dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, B, so this Wuhan coronavirus situation, uh, it's really escalated, right? I mean, the numbers are pretty grim.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, B, so this Wuhan coronavirus situation, uh, it's really escalated, right? I mean, the numbers are pretty grim.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, A, it's pretty concerning. We're talking over a hundred people dead, and like, 4,700 infected now. It's a really fast-moving situation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, A, it's pretty concerning. We're talking over a hundred people dead, and like, four thousand, seven hundred infected now. It's a really fast-moving situation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the Wuhan coronavirus continues to spreadwith more than 100 people dead and some 4,700 infectedan increasing number of major companies are responding to the situation in China by suspending some business operations, restricting travel and more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And what I'm seeing is a huge response from major companies. It's not just, you know, local businesses; big players are really pulling back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And what I'm seeing is a huge response from major companies. It's not just, you know, local businesses; big players are really pulling back.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. Disney and McDonald's were, uh, among the first last week. Disney shut down both its Shanghai and Hong Kong theme parks. And McDonald's suspended operations in five cities in Hubei Province, which, you know, is the epicenter.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. Disney and McDonald's were, uh, among the first last week. Disney shut down both its Shanghai and Hong Kong theme parks. And McDonald's suspended operations in five cities in Hubei Province, which, you know, is the epicenter.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: McDonalds and Disney were among the first companies to shutter businesses in China last week: Disney has shut down its Shanghai and Hong Kong theme parks, while McDonalds said that it had suspended business across five cities in the Hubei Province (the center of the outbreak).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And then Starbucks quickly followed suit. I saw they've closed over half of their 4,100 stores in mainland China. That's a huge number.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And then Starbucks quickly followed suit. I saw they've closed over half of their four thousand, one hundred stores in mainland China. That's a huge number.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Starbucks quickly followed suitit has now closed more than half of its 4,100 stores in mainland China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's massive. And it's not just food and entertainment. Big retailers like H&M have closed 45 locations and even, like, suspended business travel to and from China for their employees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's massive. And it's not just food and entertainment. Big retailers like H and M have closed forty five locations and even, like, suspended business travel to and from China for their employees.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Big retailers have also shut down stores with H&M closing 45 locations and suspending business travel to and from China for its employees, according to Reuters.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And others too, like IKEA and Swatch have closed stores specifically in Wuhan. And then Uniqlo, part of Fast Retailing, shuttered almost 100 stores in Hubei.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And others too, like I K E A and Swatch have closed stores specifically in Wuhan. And then Uniqlo, part of Fast Retailing, shuttered almost one hundred stores in Hubei.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Other companies such as IKEA and Swatch have closed stores in Wuhan, while Japanese conglomerate Fast Retailing shuttered nearly 100 of its Uniqlo stores in the Hubei province.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] And hotels, too! Marriott, Hyatt, Hilton—they've all suspended operations in Wuhan and wider Hubei. It's not just, like, individual businesses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And hotels, too! Marriott, Hyatt, Hilton-they've all suspended operations in Wuhan and wider Hubei. It's not just, like, individual businesses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Several hotels including Marriott, Hyatt and Hilton have also suspended some operations within Wuhan and the greater Hubei province.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Even the travel industry itself is feeling it. Carnival and Royal Caribbean Cruises have canceled several scheduled voyages. And MGM Resorts, you know, they scaled back their Lunar New Year celebration in Macao.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Even the travel industry itself is feeling it. Carnival and Royal Caribbean Cruises have canceled several scheduled voyages. And M G M Resorts, you know, they scaled back their Lunar New Year celebration in Macao.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tour operators Carnival and Royal Carribean Cruises canceled several scheduled voyages, while casino operator MGM Resorts said its scaled back its Lunar New Year celebration at its Macao resort last weekend.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's really affecting everyone. And we're also seeing a lot of companies restricting employee travel, which makes sense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's really affecting everyone. And we're also seeing a lot of companies restricting employee travel, which makes sense.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like the tech giants, Facebook and Microsoft, have asked all their employees to suspend non-essential travel to mainland China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like the tech giants, Facebook and Microsoft, have asked all their employees to suspend non-essential travel to mainland China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tech giants like Facebook and Microsoft, for example, recently asked all of its employees to suspend non-essential travel to mainland China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And big banks too, like Standard Chartered and Commonwealth Bank of Australia, they're advising employees to just avoid trips to China altogether.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And big banks too, like Standard Chartered and Commonwealth Bank of Australia, they're advising employees to just avoid trips to China altogether.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Big banks, like Standard Chartered and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, also said employee trips to China should be avoided.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Even automakers, uh, Fiat Chrysler, they've restricted travel to Wuhan and other Chinese cities. GM and Ford are doing similar for Wuhan, but not necessarily other parts yet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even automakers, uh, Fiat Chrysler, they've restricted travel to Wuhan and other Chinese cities. G M and Ford are doing similar for Wuhan, but not necessarily other parts yet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Large automakers, such as Fiat Chrysler, have also restricted travel to Wuhan as well as other Chinese cities. General Motors and Ford, while restricting business trips to Wuhan, have yet to suspend travel to other parts of China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It just shows you the scale of the government response, too, with over a dozen cities locked down. That's, like, 50 million people, um, with restricted travel.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It just shows you the scale of the government response, too, with over a dozen cities locked down. That's, like, fifty million people, um, with restricted travel.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese government has locked down more than a dozen cities in an attempt to quarantine the coronavirus resulting in restricted travel for some 50 million people and complicated it for many others.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which brings us to, what about people who already booked trips? Are they just out of luck?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which brings us to, what about people who already booked trips? Are they just out of luck?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Thankfully, no. A lot of airlines, hotels, booking platforms—they're all offering free cancellations and date changes. So, there's some relief there, at least.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Thankfully, no. A lot of airlines, hotels, booking platforms-they're all offering free cancellations and date changes. So, there's some relief there, at least.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A host of airlines, hotels, booking platforms and travel agencies are offering free cancellations and date changes for those who had earlier purchased trips to China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Good to hear. Well, it's clear this situation is having a huge global impact, and, uh, companies are reacting quickly. We'll keep an eye on this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Good to hear. Well, it's clear this situation is having a huge global impact, and, uh, companies are reacting quickly. We'll keep an eye on this.
